title: Did the Chinese Empire and the Persian Empire know each other? What was their relationship? - Quora

response.answer_text: The answer is a definite “yes” but we need to qualify which of the many Chinese dynasties and which of the Persian empires we are referring to. Though it seems counter-intuitive, and Buddhism notwithstanding, the Chinese and Persian Empires had greater contact with each other than the Chinese and Indian Empires had. It appears that the Steppes and deserts of Central Asia were less of a barrier than the Himalayas and the Tibetan Plateau. Buddhism came to China from many routes; but one of the primary routes was from Central Asia, with the Sanskrit-knowing Iranian people - the Parthians, Indo-Parthians, Yuezhi (the Kushans), etc actively promoting it. (Aside: the reason Faxian and Xuanzang made historic trips to India was to bypass such middlemen and learn directly from the source) The Silk Road connecting Persia and China was a flurry of activity during the later Tang dynasty (7th-10th century), and Sogdians - also an Eastern Iranian people who inhabited today’s Tajikistan and Uzbekistan - were a notable presence in the Tang court. A Short History and Some New Discoveries Though Central Asia later became Muslim and Turkish, Persian still emerged as its lingua franca. The Tang and Song dynasties encouraged Central Asians to settle in various parts of China. This perhaps created the seeds for the Persian-knowing Hui Muslim populations of China. Another import into China from early Muslim Persia was cobalt blue, which formed a staple of both the Chinese and Islamic ceramic wares later.  Above: Chinese ceramic made for the Persian market One of the stories in Persian folklore is a certain Prince Humay falling in love with some Princess Humayun of China. This imaginative fiction surfaced in the 14th century when the Mongol Yuan dynasty that ruled China claimed the Ilkhanate that ruled Persia as its subordinate. It was at this time that the Chinese astronomical instruments came to Persia, though astronomical exchanges between Persia and China had happened prior too. There were constant exchanges (and battles) between the later Timurid Persia ruling from Herat in Khorasan (Afghanistan) and the Ming dynasty. The biggest influence was in the field of Art. Prince Shah Rukh’s trip to the Ming court was accompanied by his chief Persian artist, Ghiyāth al-dīn Naqqāsh, who also chronicled China. Not surprisingly, the Persian artists and their patrons began to acquire Chinese tastes. We need to note here, land was not the only route for contact between medieval Persia and China. The Ming era admiral Zheng He, who was a Hui of possible Iranian origin himself, supposedly made voyages to the Persian Gulf. How much did Admiral Ming Zheng He know about India and did any Indian king meet with him? What was the political situation on the Indian continent at that time?. But the land-locked Timurids, Turks and Mongols were not seafarers but masters of the Steppes. Chinese influence on Persian art continued in the Safavid era. This painting of man and woman in embrace, below, by 17th century Reza Abbasi shows Chinese-style clouds and pale Chinese faces with elongated eyes (the man swarthier than the lady).  Interestingly, the Chinese influence on Indian Mughal art came from Persia. These Persian Mughal Ramayana miniatures (16th century), for example, has Chinese hills, Chinese trees (gnarled trunks) and a Chinese dragon for Tatakasura.  Finally, from the late 17th century onwards, with the isolationist Qing -Manchu dynasty ruling China, overseas cultural contacts ceased. The Tarim Basin which had the ancient Kingdom of Khotan and Moghulistan was absorbed into Qing empire as Xinjiang. This Encylopedia Iranica chapter details the influence of the two civilizations upon one another. CHINESE-IRANIAN RELATIONS

Yes. The two Empires in their various incarnations (Han/Tang, Parthian/Sassanid) were frequent trading partners. Since the first expeditions sent out west by Emperor Wu of Han in the 100s BCE, relations between the two empires, though distant, were good. Trade flourished along the Silk Road that first opened during the Han and Parthian dynasties, and the Persians also served as the middlemen between China and the third great civilization of Eurasia: Rome. Anxi (Parthia) is situated several thousand li west of the region of the Great Yuezi (in Transoxonia). The people are settled on the land, cultivating the fields and growing rice and wheat. They also make wine out of grapes. They have walled cities like the people of Dayuan (Ferghana), the region contains several hundred cities of various sizes. The coins of the country are made of silver and bear the face of the king. When the king dies, the currency is immediately changed and new coins issued with the face of his successor. The people keep records by writing on horizontal strips of leather. To the west lies Tiaozi (Mesopotamia) and to the north Yancai and Lixuan (Hyrcania). Zhang Qian, Chinese explorer, 126 BCE The Chinese evidently recognized that the Persians were a sophisticated society with many similarities to their civilization: currency, walled cities, settled people. On top of that, the Persians were too far away from the center of Chinese power for a military campaign against them to be profitable. A relationship as trading partners was mutually beneficial, and so China never attempted to encroach upon Persia’s sphere of influence in Central Asia.  Silver coin minted by Parthia. Coins like these have been found all throughout China. The same relationship persisted through dynastic changes in both China and Persia. Although the Han Dynasty’s collapse resulted in a fractured China, and the Sassanid dynasty came to power in Persia, both civilizations maintained trade and good relations. Both were too far from each other to do things like interfere in dynastic struggles or civil wars, but at times they did aid each other in guarding the trade routes through Central Asia, and even helped each other repel encroachment from the Hephthalites, similar to how the Persians cooperated with the Byzantines to defend the Caucasus from the Turks. Perhaps the most notable case of Sino-Persian cooperation came when the Arab Caliphate began its sweeping conquests. It tore the old balance of power in the Mediterranean to shreds, pushing the Byzantine Empire out of Africa and the Levant. The Sassanid Empire was completely destroyed by the Arab onslaught, with the last Persian king Peroz III fleeing to the court of Emperor Gaozong of Tang. The exiled Persian ruler sought military aid from the Chinese in a bid to regain his throne and push back the Arabs. Though the campaigns were unsuccessful, Peroz and other Persian refugees fleeing from the Arabs were able to make Tang China their new home, becoming one of many esteemed minorities in cosmopolitan China.  The Tang Imperial Court Your turn, Hoang! :p

They were linked by the Silk Road. There is even evidence of contacts before Cyrus the Great created the Persian Empire. They were much too distant to think of waging war on each other. Nor even to cooperate against nomads, who were different on the borders of each Empire. China pushed out some nomads who may later have emerged as the Huns in the West.

It was recorded in China history book “the book of Tang 唐书” that during Emporor Gaozong’s reign the last Persian crown prince, Peroz III (پیروز سوم) had fled from the invasion of Arab empire to China and pledged for Tang’s help to restore his country, but China at that time was focusing on dealing with western Turks. The prince died of age in China later.
